segment.source: Fixing blurry text in Windows 8.1 for IT Professionals
segment.target: Fixing blurry text in Windows 8.1 for IT Professionals

segment.source: Fixing blurry text in Windows 8.1 for IT Professionals
segment.target: Fixing blurry text in Windows 8.1 for IT Professionals

segment.source: Fixing blurry text in Windows 8.1 for IT Professionals
segment.target: Fixing blurry text in Windows 8.1 for IT Professionals

segment.source: Windows® desktop apps fall broadly into two classes: apps that are DPI-aware and those that are not.
segment.target: Windows® desktop apps fall broadly into two classes: apps that are DPI-aware and those that are not.

segment.source: DPI-aware apps actively let Windows know during application launch that they are capable of scaling themselves to work well on a high DPI display.
segment.target: DPI-aware apps actively let Windows know during application launch that they are capable of scaling themselves to work well on a high DPI display.

segment.source: These apps include: Internet Explorer, Office, Firefox, and .NET 2.0+ (including WPF) apps.
segment.target: These apps include: Internet Explorer, Office, Firefox, and .NET 2.0+ (including WPF) apps.

segment.source: These apps generally work well across a wide range of scale factors.
segment.target: These apps generally work well across a wide range of scale factors.

segment.source: Therefore, if your enterprise line of business apps are also DPI-aware, your users should not have a problem with any Windows 8.1 displays or scale factors.
segment.target: Therefore, if your enterprise line of business apps are also DPI-aware, your users should not have a problem with any Windows 8.1 displays or scale factors.

segment.source: However, if an application is not DPI aware, and is running on a high DPI display, Windows scales the app by applying bitmap scaling to the application output.
segment.target: However, if an application is not DPI aware, and is running on a high DPI display, Windows scales the app by applying bitmap scaling to the application output.

segment.source: This ensures that the application is the correct size on a high DPI display.
segment.target: This ensures that the application is the correct size on a high DPI display.

segment.source: In most instances this will result in crisp and usable applications, but in some instances, the result is less crisp and might have a slightly fuzzy or blurry appearance because of the bitmap scaling.
segment.target: In most instances this will result in crisp and usable applications, but in some instances, the result is less crisp and might have a slightly fuzzy or blurry appearance because of the bitmap scaling.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.target: How to tell if an application is not DPI-aware

segment.target: What you can do about apps that aren’t DPI-aware

segment.source: Tell Windows not to scale an app that’s not DPI-aware
segment.target: Tell Windows not to scale an app that’s not DPI-aware

segment.source: How to tell if an application is not DPI-aware
segment.target: How to tell if an application is not DPI-aware

segment.source: Use the Process Explorer tool to determine if an app is DPI-aware.
segment.target: Use the Process Explorer tool to determine if an app is DPI-aware.

segment.source: Figure 1 Process Explorer shows this utility in use, with the column for DPI Awareness enabled.
segment.target: Figure 1 Process Explorer shows this utility in use, with the column for DPI Awareness enabled.

segment.source: (By default, process explorer does not show the DPI Awareness column.
segment.target: (By default, process explorer does not show the DPI Awareness column.

segment.source: To turn this column on, click the View menu, click Select Columns, check the box for DPI Awareness, and click OK.) The column titled DPI Awareness tells you whether a particular process is aware of DPI or not.
segment.target: To turn this column on, click the View menu, click Select Columns, check the box for DPI Awareness, and click OK.) The column titled DPI Awareness tells you whether a particular process is aware of DPI or not.

segment.source: process explorer - sysinternals
segment.target: process explorer - sysinternals

segment.source: Figure 1 Process Explorer
segment.target: Figure 1 Process Explorer

segment.source: Windows 8.1 distinguishes between three classes of applications.
segment.target: Windows 8.1 distinguishes between three classes of applications.

segment.source: Table 1 DPI Awareness Apps
segment.target: Table 1 DPI Awareness Apps

segment.source: DPI awareness
segment.target: DPI awareness

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Behavior
segment.target: Behavior

segment.source: Unaware
segment.target: Unaware

segment.source: Mmc.exe (Microsoft Management Console and its plugins)
segment.target: Mmc.exe (Microsoft Management Console and its plugins)

segment.source: Windows bitmap scales the application to any high DPI displays that are attached to the system; can be fuzzy at 125% and 150% scale factors.
segment.target: Windows bitmap scales the application to any high DPI displays that are attached to the system; can be fuzzy at 125% and 150% scale factors.

segment.source: System-aware
segment.target: System-aware

segment.source: Office apps
segment.target: Office apps

segment.source: Application scales itself at launch to the system DPI (usually the same as the primary display DPI); Windows scales the app to any displays that do not match this.
segment.target: Application scales itself at launch to the system DPI (usually the same as the primary display DPI); Windows scales the app to any displays that do not match this.

segment.source: Per-monitor-aware
segment.target: Per-monitor-aware

segment.source: Internet Explorer 11
segment.target: Internet Explorer 11

segment.source: Application dynamically scales itself to the display DPI.
segment.target: Application dynamically scales itself to the display DPI.

segment.source: What you can do about apps that aren’t DPI-aware
segment.target: What you can do about apps that aren’t DPI-aware

segment.source: Run the latest version of the app or ask the application vendor to update their app to be DPI aware
segment.target: Run the latest version of the app or ask the application vendor to update their app to be DPI aware

segment.source: Microsoft recommends that all applications become DPI-aware.
segment.target: Microsoft recommends that all applications become DPI-aware.

segment.source: It is possible that newer versions of your applications are already DPI-aware.
segment.target: It is possible that newer versions of your applications are already DPI-aware.

segment.source: If they are not, you can ask your app vendor to update their app to be DPI aware.
segment.target: If they are not, you can ask your app vendor to update their app to be DPI aware.

segment.source: Microsoft provides developer resources that can help them update their app, including the following:
segment.target: Microsoft provides developer resources that can help them update their app, including the following:

segment.source: Making Your Desktop Apps Shine on High- DPI Displays (BUILD 2013 presentation)
segment.target: Making Your Desktop Apps Shine on High- DPI Displays (BUILD 2013 presentation)

segment.source: Writing DPI-Aware Desktop Applications in Windows 8.1
segment.target: Writing DPI-Aware Desktop Applications in Windows 8.1

segment.source: Dynamic DPI sample
segment.target: Dynamic DPI sample

segment.source: Tell Windows not to scale an app that’s not DPI-aware
segment.target: Tell Windows not to scale an app that’s not DPI-aware

segment.source: In the cases where users cannot deal with the bitmap scaling of apps that aren’t DPI-aware (for example, 125% scaling and fuzzy applications), individual Windows desktop applications can be shimmed to not be scaled.
segment.target: In the cases where users cannot deal with the bitmap scaling of apps that aren’t DPI-aware (for example, 125% scaling and fuzzy applications), individual Windows desktop applications can be shimmed to not be scaled.

segment.source: Users can do this by using the Compatibility tab of the application’s Properties UI.
segment.target: Users can do this by using the Compatibility tab of the application’s Properties UI.

segment.source: For example, Figure 2 Application Properties shows how a user can disable bitmap scaling:
segment.target: For example, Figure 2 Application Properties shows how a user can disable bitmap scaling:

segment.source: application properties
segment.target: application properties

segment.source: Figure 2 Application Properties
segment.target: Figure 2 Application Properties

segment.source: You can manage bulk-shimming of applications by using the Compatadmin tool, which is available in the Application Compatibility Toolkit that is included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK).
segment.target: You can manage bulk-shimming of applications by using the Compatadmin tool, which is available in the Application Compatibility Toolkit that is included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK).

segment.source: You can download the Windows ADK from Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows® 8.
segment.target: You can download the Windows ADK from Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows® 8.

segment.source: For more information about how to use the Compatadmin tool, see How to use the Compatibility Administrator utility in Windows.
segment.target: For more information about how to use the Compatadmin tool, see How to use the Compatibility Administrator utility in Windows.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Disabling display scaling can result in content that is too small to be read or interacted with reliably; it can also produce visual artifacts such as clipped or overlapped content.
segment.target: Disabling display scaling can result in content that is too small to be read or interacted with reliably; it can also produce visual artifacts such as clipped or overlapped content.

segment.source: These issues depend on details of how the app was written.
segment.target: These issues depend on details of how the app was written.

segment.source: Consequently, we recommend only changing this setting if absolutely required.
segment.target: Consequently, we recommend only changing this setting if absolutely required.

segment.source: This shim should not be applied to apps that do not require it, or to devices that do not require it.
segment.target: This shim should not be applied to apps that do not require it, or to devices that do not require it.

segment.source: Use Windows 8 DPI scaling (not generally recommended)
segment.target: Use Windows 8 DPI scaling (not generally recommended)

segment.source: Windows 8.1 includes a Windows 8 compatibility scaling mode that can be deployed to address all visual blurring issues with certain displays.
segment.target: Windows 8.1 includes a Windows 8 compatibility scaling mode that can be deployed to address all visual blurring issues with certain displays.

segment.source: Note that using the compatibility mode turns off all the benefits of the Windows 8.1 DPI features.
segment.target: Note that using the compatibility mode turns off all the benefits of the Windows 8.1 DPI features.

segment.source: This method should only be used as a last resort, if the enterprise environment includes too many apps that aren’t DPI-aware to be mitigated by applying application shimming.
segment.target: This method should only be used as a last resort, if the enterprise environment includes too many apps that aren’t DPI-aware to be mitigated by applying application shimming.

segment.source: Users can access this mode in the DPI CPL UI by checking the box that says Let me choose one scaling level for all my displays:
segment.target: Users can access this mode in the DPI CPL UI by checking the box that says Let me choose one scaling level for all my displays:

segment.source: display
segment.target: display

segment.source: Figure 3 Scaling Level Option
segment.target: Figure 3 Scaling Level Option

segment.source: This setting can also be applied during deployment if you have many specific apps that need remediation and you plan a large scale roll-out to low or mid-density displays.
segment.target: This setting can also be applied during deployment if you have many specific apps that need remediation and you plan a large scale roll-out to low or mid-density displays.

segment.source: You can customize your image in Audit mode before deployment.
segment.target: You can customize your image in Audit mode before deployment.

segment.source: See Audit Mode Overview.
segment.target: See Audit Mode Overview.

segment.source: See also the next section that explains how to programmatically perform device detection and registry customization.
segment.target: See also the next section that explains how to programmatically perform device detection and registry customization.

segment.source: Understanding high DPI, display types, and Windows scaling
segment.target: Understanding high DPI, display types, and Windows scaling

segment.source: Windows 8.1 scales apps that aren’t DPI-aware dynamically by resizing the bitmap generated by the application.
segment.target: Windows 8.1 scales apps that aren’t DPI-aware dynamically by resizing the bitmap generated by the application.

segment.source: Bitmap scaling works best when scaled at integer multiples (for example, 1x, 2x, 3x), but can have visual artifacts that are often perceived as blurry/fuzzy at non-integer multiples (for example, 125%, 150%.)
segment.target: Bitmap scaling works best when scaled at integer multiples (for example, 1x, 2x, 3x), but can have visual artifacts that are often perceived as blurry/fuzzy at non-integer multiples (for example, 125%, 150%.)

segment.source: Windows supports a full spectrum of screen sizes, resolutions, and therefore DPI.
segment.target: Windows supports a full spectrum of screen sizes, resolutions, and therefore DPI.

segment.source: There will be some DPI ranges that result in less than optimal Windows scaling for apps that aren’t DPI-aware.
segment.target: There will be some DPI ranges that result in less than optimal Windows scaling for apps that aren’t DPI-aware.

segment.source: Table 2 Scaling Values describes the possible issues that users can encounter at different Windows scaling values:
segment.target: Table 2 Scaling Values describes the possible issues that users can encounter at different Windows scaling values:

segment.source: Table 2 Scaling Values
segment.target: Table 2 Scaling Values

segment.target: Scale factor

segment.target: 100% mainstream

segment.target: 125% value

segment.target: 150% premium

segment.target: 200% premium

segment.target: Scaling benefit

segment.target: N/A

segment.target: Small size improvement

segment.target: Significant size improvement

segment.target: Critical size improvement

segment.target: Bitmap scaling of unaware apps

segment.source: N/A
segment.target: N/A

segment.target: Most noticeable fuzziness

segment.target: Less noticeable fuzziness

segment.source: Clear and crisp
segment.target: Clear and crisp

segment.source: Scaling of aware apps
segment.target: Scaling of aware apps

segment.target: N/A

segment.source: Clear and crisp
segment.target: Clear and crisp

segment.target: Clear and crisp

segment.source: Clear and crisp
segment.target: Clear and crisp

segment.source: As shown in the preceding table, most of the issues manifest at the 125% scaling ratio.
segment.target: As shown in the preceding table, most of the issues manifest at the 125% scaling ratio.

segment.source: For this reason, any mitigation should target apps that aren’t DPI-aware on 125% scaling systems only.
segment.target: For this reason, any mitigation should target apps that aren’t DPI-aware on 125% scaling systems only.

segment.source: For information about how to identify 125% systems or how to revert to Windows 8 scaling behavior for a 125% system, see DPI-related APIs and registry settings.
segment.target: For information about how to identify 125% systems or how to revert to Windows 8 scaling behavior for a 125% system, see DPI-related APIs and registry settings.
